column3: U-64 (Kptlt. Georg-Wilhelm Schulz). Sunk on 13 April 1940 in the Herjangsfjord north-east of Narvik
column7: by a bomb from a Swordfish aircraft (700 Sqn FAA/L9767) carried on the British battleship HMS Warspite.

column3: U-49 (Kptlt. Kurt von Gossler). Sunk on 15 April 1940 in the Norwegian Sea north-east of Harstad
column6: by depth charges from the British destroyers HMS Fearless and HMS Brazen.

column3: U-655 (KrvKpt. Adolf Dumrese). Sunk on 24 March 1942 in the Barents Sea south-east of Bear Island
column6: by ramming from the British minesweeper HMS Sharpshooter.

column3: U-585 (Kptlt. Ernst-Bernward Lohse). Sunk on or about 30 March 1942 in the Barents Sea north-east of Rybachy Peninsula
column6: by a drifting mine from the German barrage Bantos-A.

column3: U-88 (Kptlt. Heino Bohmann). Sunk on 12 September 1942 in the Arctic Sea south-west of Spitzbergen
column6: by depth charges from the British destroyer HMS Faulknor.

column3: U-589 (KrvKpt. Hans-Joachim Horrer). Sunk on 14 September 1942 in the Barents Sea south of Spitzbergen
column6: by depth charges from the British destroyer HMS Onslow and a Swordfish aircraft (825 Sqn FAA) of the British escort carrier HMS Avenger. Four Luftwaffe aircrew rescued the day before were lost with the crew of 44.

column3: U-457 (KrvKpt. Karl Brandenburg). Sunk on 16 September 1942 in the Barents Sea west of Novaya Zemlya
column6: by depth charges from the British destroyer HMS Impulsive.

column3: U-314 (Kptlt. Georg-Wilhelm Basse). Sunk on 30 January 1944 in the Barents Sea south-east of Bear Island
column6: by depth charges from the British destroyer HMS Inconstant.

column3: U-601 (Oblt. Otto Hansen). Sunk on 25 February 1944 in the Norwegian Sea north-west of Narvik
column7: by depth charges from a British Catalina aircraft (210 Sqn RAF/M).

column3: U-472 (Oblt. Wolfgang-Friedrich Freiherr von Forstner). Sunk on 4 March 1944 in the Barents Sea south-east of Bear Island
column6: by gunfire and rockets from the British destroyer HMS Onslaught and a Swordfish aircraft (816 Sqn FAA/B) of the British escort carrier HMS Chaser.

column3: U-366 (Oblt. (R) Bruno Langenberg). Sunk on 5 March 1944 in the Norwegian Sea north-west of Hammerfest
column6: by rockets from a Swordfish aircraft (816 Sqn FAA/F) of the British escort carrier HMS Chaser.

column3: U-973 (Oblt. Klaus Paepenmöller). Sunk on 6 March 1944 in the Norwegian Sea north-west of Narvik
column7: by rockets from a Swordfish aircraft (816 Sqn FAA/X) of the British escort carrier HMS Chaser.

column3: U-355 (KrvKpt. Günter La Baume). Missing since 1 April 1944 in the Norwegian Sea south-west of Bear Island. There is no explanation for its loss.
U-360 (Kptlt. Klaus-Helmuth Becker). Sunk on 2 April 1944 in the Norwegian Sea south-west of Bear Island
column6: by depth charges from the British destroyer HMS Keppel.

column3: U-288 (Oblt. (R) Willy Meyer). Sunk on 3 April 1944 in the Barents Sea east of Bear Island
column6: by depth charges
column7: rockets and strafing from a British Swordfish aircraft (819 Sqn FAA/C) of the British escort carrier HMS Activity and the British Avenger & Wildcat aircraft (846 Sqn FAA/G & Y) of the British escort carrier HMS Tracker.

column3: U-277 (Kptlt. Robert Lübsen). Sunk on 1 May 1944 in the Norwegian Sea south-west of Bear Island
column6: by depth charges from a British Swordfish aircraft (842 Sqn FAA/C) from the British escort carrier HMS Fencer.

column3: U-674 (Oblt. Harald Muhs). Sunk on 2 May 1944 in the Norwegian Sea east of Jan Mayen Island
column6: by rockets from a Swordfish aircraft (842 Sqn FAA/B) of the British escort carrier HMS Fencer.

column3: U-987 (Oblt. Hilmar-Karl Schreyer). Sunk on 15 June 1944 in the Norwegian Sea west of Narvik
column6: by torpedoes from the British submarine HMS Satyr.

column3: U-347 (Oblt. Johann de Buhr). Sunk on 17 July 1944 in the Norwegian Sea west of Narvik
column7: by depth charges from a British Liberator aircraft (86 Sqn RAF/U).

column3: U-361 (Kptlt. Hans Seidel). Sunk in 17 July 1944 in the Norwegian Sea west of Narvik
column7: by depth charges from a British Catalina aircraft (210 Sqn RAF/Y).

column3: U-742 (Kptlt. Heinz Schwassmann). Sunk on 18 July 1944 in the Norwegian Sea west of Narvik
column7: by depth charges from a British Catalina aircraft (210 Sqn RAF/Z).

column3: U-344 (Kptlt. Ulrich Pietsch). Sunk on 22 August 1944 in the Norwegian Sea north-west of Bear Island
column6: by depth charges from a British Swordfish aircraft (825 Sqn FAA/X) of the British escort carrier HMS Vindex.

column3: U-354 (Oblt. Hans-Jürgen Sthamer). Sunk on 24 August 1944 in the Barents Sea north-east of North Cape
column6: by depth charges from the British sloop HMS Mermaid and the British frigate HMS Loch Dunvegan.

column3: U-394 (Kptlt. Wolfgang Borger). Sunk on 2 September 1944 in the Norwegian Sea south-east of Jan Mayen Island
column6: by rockets and depth charges from a Swordfish aircraft (825 Sqn FAA/V) of the British escort carrier HMS Vindex
column7: the British destroyers HMS Keppel and HMS Whitehall and the British sloops HMS Mermaid and HMS Peacock.

column3: U-921 (Oblt. (R) Alfred Werner). Missing since 24 September 1944 in the Norwegian Sea west of Bear Island. There is no explanation for its loss.
U-957 (Oblt. Gerd Schaar). Decommissioned and cannibalized for spare parts on 21 October 1944 at Narvik
column4:
after being damaged by pack ice in the Kara Sea on 18 September 1944.

Hulk probably scuttled in the Skjömenfjord in May 1945.

column3: U-771 (Oblt. (R) Helmut Block). Sunk on 11 November 1944 in the Norwegian Sea in the Andfjord near Harstad
column7: by torpedoes from the British submarine HMS Venturer.

column3: U-387 (Kptlt. Rudolf Büchler). Sunk on 9 December 1944 in the Barents Sea east of the Rybachy Peninsula
column6: by depth charges from the British corvette HMS Bamborough Castle.

column3: U-365 (Oblt. Diether Todenhagen). Sunk on 13 December 1944 in the Norwegian Sea east of Jan Mayen Island
column6: by depth charges from two Swordfish aircraft (813 Sqn FAA/L & Q) of the British escort carrier HMS Campania.

column3: U-737 (Oblt. Friedrich-August Greus). Sank at 0018hrs on 19 December 1944 in the Norwegian Sea in the Vestfjord
column6: after a collision with the German minesweeping ship MRS 25.

column3: U-425 (Kptlt. Heinz Bentzien). Sunk on 17 February 1945 in the Barents Sea east of Rybachy Peninsula

column3: U-307 (Oblt. (R) Erich Krüger). Sunk on 29 April 1945 in the Barents Sea off Kola Inlet

column3: U-286 (Oblt. Willi Dietrich). Sunk on 29 April 1945 in the Barents Sea off Kola Inlet
column6: by depth charges from the British frigates HMS Loch Insh
